page.title: 03SOILS AND STREAMS: WARLEY
page.content: The poor drainage of the London Clay has led to the formation of large areas of{Stagnogley}soils - although the artificial drainage of these soils has been much in evidence in recent years. In contrast, the supposedly poorer parent material on the late Tertiary/Pleistocene beds has been left to support woodland - leading to the development of paradoxically richer soils -{Argillic Brown Earths and{Brown Earths. Some streams flow estwards into the {Weald Brook,}which here marks the boundary between Essex and Greater London, and which joins the Thames near Rainham. Others flow eastwards into the{Mar Dyke}which crosses the Essex Marshes to join the Thames lower down, near Purfleet.
